title: Luxury brands go to great lengths to find right spot for shops in Sydney
text:
An artist's impression of the new retail development at the MLC Centre.
Luxury retailers are calling Sydney home with a plethora of big names itching to enter the country when an appropriate site for a flagship store can be found.
In a sign of the shift in shopping demographics, more overseas tourists are visiting to take advantage of the lower Australian dollar and buy luxe items.
The brands gathering in the international departure lounges awaiting clearance to land – initially in Sydney and Melbourne – include Alexander McQueen, Balenciaga, Boucheron, Brioni, Celine, Chloe, Chopard, Dolce & Gabbana, Donna Karan, Dunhill, Emilio Pucci, Fendi, Givenchy, Goyard, Graff, Harry Winston, Hearts on Fire and celebrity favourites Tom Ford, Valentino, Van Cleef & Arpels.
High-end apparel store Collection of Style (COS) is due to open soon in Martin Place, as is German luxury luggage brand Rimowa.
Advertisement Luxury labels are keen to be clustered together to ensure maximum impact, as evidenced by the fast-fashion names that have made Pitt Street Mall home.
Knight Frank's senior director of retail leasing, Alex Alamsyah​, said the longevity of luxury retail brands in Australia's CBDs showed no signs of weakening as the influx of wealthy Asian tourists continued to shop in these key luxury fashion precincts.
"The Chinese market accounts for over 25 per cent of the global luxury market, overtaking the Japanese as the world's largest luxury shopper, and about 75 per cent of Chinese luxury purchases take place outside mainland China," Mr Alamsyah said.
"So with more than 100 million Chinese people travelling abroad, including, but not limited to, New York, London, Paris and Sydney, global luxury retailers are keen to expand to these cities."
Mr Alamsyah said in the past few years, affordable international fast-fashion brands like H&M, Zara, Uniqlo and Topshop had expanded across Australia's CBDs.
However, in the next two to three years, it would be the "years of luxury brands" attacking the Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane CBDs.
Meanwhile, the competition for sites was strong.
As recently reported by BusinessDay , banks and telcos were fighting back against fashion retailers for prime shops in the Sydney CBD, including in George Street and Pitt Street Mall.
However, some landlords still preferred the prestige of luxury and international retailers for their properties, despite banks and telcos being able to pay $7000 to $15,000-plus per square metre per annum in George Street and Pitt Street Mall, respectively.
Mr Alamsyah said while demand was strong, location remained the key.
"It is dependent on which part of George Street for luxury. Say, for example, if it is the corner of George and King streets at 388 George Street, then luxury retailers will say 'yes', as it has direct access from [the] Louis Vuitton building to Chanel/Dior in King Street; otherwise, luxury retailers will say 'no' as George Street is still a mix of everything from fast food, such as McDonald's, to souvenir stores and convenience stores," Mr Alamsyah.
George Street is also a deterrent for some retailers as it undergoes years of construction to become a pedestrian zone. As a result, King Street is viewed as the future of the luxury precincts.
Mr Alamsyah said, potentially, Brookfield/Investa Office Fund might refurbish 388 George Street in 2018-19; and DEXUS Property might refurbish 175 Pitt Street at the same time.
"It is also understood that Victor Comino​ might remix the Wittner Shoes building at 138 Pitt Street and a new super luxury retailer will take over the ex-Tag Heuer [spot] at 119 King Street and last, but not least, private owners who have bought the Trust Building at 155 King Street/72 Castlereagh Street might also activate this corner into a true luxury brand opportunity," he said.
It is understood that Knight Frank is assisting these property owners.
"Furthermore, the ultimate future for the super luxury is Castlereagh Street as GPT/QIC might start their retail redevelopment in 2016-17 on the corner of King and Castlereagh streets, being the MLC Centre," Mr Alamsyah said.
The upmarket Hermes was yet to make a final decision on a new Sydney site, despite speculation it had signed at the MLC Centre.
Knight Frank and Tim Green Commercial are working with the owners of 112 Castlereagh Street to remix the Commonwealth Bank building at the corner of Castlereagh and Market streets, opposite Prada/Gucci and David Jones.
"Therefore, with so many options in King Street and Castlereagh Street for luxury retailers to choose from, George Street might only get premium/semi-luxury retailers but luxury/super-luxury retailers will go to King and Castlereagh streets", Mr Alamsyah said.
Knight Frank's director of retail leasing, Michael Hanscomb,​ said: "The high demand from international luxury brands is not only strong in Sydney, but is also very strong on the east coast of Australia with Melbourne's Collins Street and Brisbane's Edward Street being in highest demand."
Mr Alamsyah said Louis Vuitton, Prada, Gucci, Dior, Chanel, Cartier, Rolex and Patek Philippe had established flagship stores in the Sydney CBD, but Hermes, Bottega Veneta​ and Burberry might have not found their ideal homes yet as either their existing stores were too small or too old or too bulky or too hidden inside a shopping centre with not enough street exposure for brand image.
